title: Navigating Stereotype Threats in Heading Recall Performance
text:
Collaborators: Cami Streuly, Shirley Du, and Cole Kaforey
Instructor: Abigail Noyce
This project explored how gender stereotype threat influences memory performance through a heading-recall task. We collected data from 35 participants across 1,400+ trials, cleaned the dataset in Excel, and analyzed results in Jamovi using ANOVA. While effects were not statistically significant, likely due in part to the small sample size, we observed suggestive patterns indicating that stereotype threat may influence recall. Findings were presented at the CMU Department of Psychology undergraduate poster session.

title: Investigating Relational Rule Learning
text:
Collaborators/Advisors: Julia Conti (graduate mentor) and Paulo Carvalho (PI)
This project investigated relational rule learning, focusing on how understanding a relational rule affects mastery rates across tasks of varying difficulty, whether prior rule-specific training improves accuracy, and whether interleaved pretraining enhances performance. Using participant data provided by Julia Conti, I applied multilevel modeling for the first time, learning the technique as the project required, to analyze performance outcomes. The results highlighted patterns in how prior training and interleaved pretraining influenced task accuracy.

title: Mapping Obesity: A County-Level Analysis of Lifestyle and Food Environment Factors
text:
Collaborators: Anvith Thumma and Jordan Faustin
This project examined county-level determinants of adult obesity in the U.S., focusing on physical inactivity and access to healthy food. Using the 2025 County Health Rankings & Roadmaps dataset, we performed exploratory analyses including scatter plots and correlation matrices, and fitted a Huber regression model to identify which predictors best explain regional variation in obesity rates. Results revealed strong associations, though the analysis is correlational, not causal. We presented our findings to UnitedHealth Group professionals and statistics faculty, including a Q&A session.

title: Predicting Flight Delays in Pittsburgh
text:
Collaborator: Emily Jiang
Instructor: Spencer Koerner
This project predicted flight delays at Pittsburgh International Airport using historical data from 2022 and 2023. My partner and I trained a random forest classifier to forecast 2024 delays, achieving 78% prediction accuracy. The project provided hands-on experience applying machine learning techniques to real-world transportation data.

title: Bookshelf
text:
Favorite Quotes





Widget by Goodreads



Favorite Books




































Favorite Comics
I’ve read a ton of X-Men over the years. Beyond the powers and fight scenes, what sticks with me is how it reflects real-world struggles faced by marginalized communities. I’ve always loved how Magneto and Professor X parallel Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. That contrast in ideology makes the story hit harder. I love the series so much that I used to have a whole screenshot stash of the funniest X-Men moments, but it got lost somewhere along the way. So here’s to starting fresh and rebuilding the archive.

title: Impact of Incentives on Visual Search Performance
text:
Collaborators: Cami Streuly, Shirley Du, and Cole Kaforey
Instructor: Abigail Noyce
This project examined whether incentives improve visual search efficiency. We collected data from participants completing multiple search trials in Gorilla, then cleaned and analyzed the dataset in Jamovi using ANOVA. While incentives showed some influence on efficiency, their overall impact on performance was modest and not statistically significant, likely due in part to the limited sample size.

title: Examining Gender Stereotype Threats on Academic Performance
text:
Collaborators: Amor Ai, Sisley Yang, Frank Janicke, Eesha Nagpal, and Camille Chandler
Instructor: Phoebe Lam
This project investigated how gender stereotype threats affect academic outcomes through a meta-analysis. Our team screened 117 studies and independently extracted effect sizes from 13 peer-reviewed articles. Using R, we synthesized the data to evaluate intervention effects. Results showed that both affirmative and non-affirmative interventions improved performance compared to no intervention, though subgroup analyses were limited by sample size.

title: Exploring Mental Health Among COVID-19 Graduates
text:
Instructor: Roberto Vargas
This independent project examined mental health differences between the undergraduate classes of 2020 and 2021, who graduated during different phases of the COVID-19 pandemic (peak vs. decline). I evaluated 100+ survey responses and applied statistical modeling (PCA, logistic regression) and bootstrap sampling techniques in R to build and validate five predictive models. Results suggested that students graduating during the pandemic’s decline experienced greater psychological distress compared to those graduating at its peak.

title: Statistical Insights into Medical Incident Records
text:
Collaborators: Emily Zhu, Sophia Mou, Alva He, Derek Gao, and Edward Brownhill
This project analyzed medical incident records for Mainstay Life Services, a nonprofit supporting individuals with intellectual disabilities and autism in residential and home settings. Our team examined patterns in incident types, needs levels, and time-to-report using Fisher’s exact tests, time series modeling, survival analysis, and Kruskal–Wallis tests. My primary contribution focused on medication error incidents, producing a detailed statistical report alongside the team’s presentation.

title: Helen Peng
text:
I’m a senior at Carnegie Mellon University, majoring in Statistics with a concentration in Psychology. I’m interested in using data to address real-world challenges, especially in public health and education. Currently, I am a member of OAK Lab where I’m investigating relational rule learning, how people learn and discover complex rules.
I like to spend my free time exploring stories, through books, TV shows, and media, that reveal how people think, connect, and navigate the world. If you’re curious, you can find a few of my favorites under the bookshelf tab.
